sections.text:
Contents lists available at ScienceDirect
Advanced Powder Technology

Original Research Paper
Experimental investigation and FE simulation of nano-indentation on Al–Al2O3 nanocomposites
http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.apt.2016.01.021 0921-8831/ 2016 The Society of Powder Technology Japan. Published by Elsevier B.V. and The Society of Powder Technology Japan. All rights reserved.
⇑ Corresponding author. Tel.: +20 34 617055836. E-mail addresses: ahmedwagih@zu.edu.eg, eng_awa2011@yahoo.com (A. Wagih),
afmeselhy@zu.edu.eg (A. Fathy).
Please cite this article in press as: A. Wagih, A. Fathy, Experimental investigation and FE simulation of nano-indentation on Al–Al2O3 nanocom Advanced Powder Technology (2016), http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.apt.2016.01.021
A. Wagih ⇑, A. Fathy Mechanical Design and Production Dept., Faculty of Engineering, Zagazig University, P.O. Box 44519, Zagazig, Sharkia, Egypt
a r t i c l e i n f o
Article history: Received 22 March 2015 Received in revised form 18 January 2016 Accepted 20 January 2016 Available online xxxx
Keywords: Finite element simulation Nano-indentation experiment Hardness Nanocomposite
a b s t r a c t
The main purpose of this paper is to investigate the nano-indentation test method and validation of its finite element simulation (FE). In the first stage, a series of nano-indentation tests were performed on the Al–Al2O3 nanocomposites by using Triboscope system and Berkovich indenter to obtain its hardness. To prepare the Al–Al2O3 nanocomposites, a pre-alloyed powder was milled in a planetary ball mill followed by cold compaction and sintering. Then in the second stage, the nano-indentation process on Al–Al2O3 nanocomposites was simulated by a 2D axisymmetric finite element (FE) model. Using the same projected area to depth function as the standard Berkovich indenter, a conical indenter with half angle 70.3 was considered in simulations. The results showed that, a homogenous distribution of the nanosized Al2O3 particles in the Al matrix was achieved after 20 h milling. The young’s modulus, yield strength, and hardness of the produced nanocomposite were increased than the pure aluminum. The results of load–displacement curve obtained from the finite element simulation of non-sharp indenter showed a good agreement with that obtained from the nano-indentation experiment. The scatter of the FE results than the experimental results in the pure aluminum is smaller than that observed for the nanocomposite. 2016 The Society of Powder Technology Japan. Published by Elsevier B.V. and The Society of Powder
Technology Japan. All rights reserved.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
In recent years, metal-matrix composites (MMCs) have replaced conventional materials for many structural and tribological components due to their superior mechanical properties, such as light weight, high stiffness and strength, and excellent wear and creep resistance. During the last two decades, a lot of research has been conducted on aluminum matrix composites (AMCs). An optimum combination of high strength and ductility gives aluminum based metal matrix composites (AMCs) a wide range of possible advanced applications. The most important AMCs applications in aerospace and infrastructure industries are enabled by functional properties including high structural efficiency, excellent wear resistance, and attractive thermal and electrical characteristics [1–5].
Powder metallurgy is considered as a good technique in producing metal-matrix composites. An important advantage of this method is its low processing temperature compared to melting techniques. Therefore, interaction between the matrix and the
reinforcement phases is prevented. On the other hand, good distribution of the reinforcing particles can be achieved. Another advantage of powder metallurgy technique is in its ability to manufacture near net shape product with low cost [6–10].
As a fair judge on this new material to decide the percentage of enhancement in the properties is to measure the mechanical properties of the composites and compare it with the properties of the conversional materials. Different mechanical test methods are available to measure the mechanical properties of materials. Uniaxial tensile test is a conventional method for measuring the mechanical properties like Young’s modulus, yield strength, strain hardening, toughness and tensile strength. Conventional mechanical test methods are often destructive and need relatively large amount of sample materials. Recently, some researchers start to use the nano-indentation technique to measure the mechanical properties of both bulk materials and thin coatings [11–13]. Since in the nano-indentation test the indentation depth is in the order of nanometer and the residual indentation diameter is often in the order of nanometer, this test needs less sample material, decreases costs and is independent of the specimen geometry.
In the last two decade, the use of finite element methods (FEM) for modeling different engineering problems was really increased. Indentation process was investigated using FEM by
posites,
many researchers to investigate the stress and strain fields under the indenter tip which are used to determine the basic mechanical properties of materials [14–16]. Considering an appropriate value for the dimensions of sample material, indenter and indentation depth, finite element modeling can also be used for simulating the nano-indentation process. Some researchers have compared the results obtained from the FE simulation of nano-indentation and from the experiment to validate finite element modeling of the nano-indentation process [17–20]. They have shown that the finite element simulation could be an appropriate method for determination of bulk material hardness.
In this paper, first, Al–Al2O3 nanocomposites were prepared using mechanical milling followed by cold compaction and sintering. Next, the uniaxial tensile test and the nano-indentation experiment were performed on the produced nanocomposites. The nano-indentation test was also simulated by finite element method to determine the stress field under the indenter and to calculate hardness of nanocomposites. Then, a comparison between the results of nano-indentation test and FE simulation was performed to validate the procedure used for finite element modeling of nano-indentation experiment on nanocomposites. Fig. 1 shows the sequence of the paper and illustrate the methodology followed during this work.

sections.heading: 2.1. Materials and processing
sections.text:
Commercial pure aluminum powder with an average particle size of 80 lm and 99.5% purity and Al2O3 (99.5% purity 80 lm size) were used as raw materials for composite fabrication. The composite powders of Al with 0 and 5 wt.% Al2O3 were milled for 20 h in a Fritsch planetary ball mill using a hardened stainless steel vial and hardened steel balls of 5 and 10 mm in diameter. A 500 ml vial was used to prepare the composite where the total amount of powder
Please cite this article in press as: A. Wagih, A. Fathy, Experimental investiga Advanced Powder Technology (2016), http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.apt.2016.01.0
was 25 g in each path. The ratio of balls to powder weight and rotational speed were 20:1 and 250 rpm, respectively. Stearic acid (3 wt.%) was used as the process control agent to prevent excessive cold welding of powder particles. The total milling time considered in this study is 20 h as suggested in [5,21,22] to achieve the homogenous reinforcement particles distribution in the matrix. Specimens were prepared through powder metallurgy technique at a compaction pressure of 600 MPa, then sintered in a hydrogen atmosphere at 500 C for 5 h. Sintering is performed in a laboratory electro resistance tube furnace with maximum power 3 kW and thermoregulation 1 C. The heating and cooling rates are 10 C/min and 2 C/min, respectively. After sintering, the specimens were hot extruded at 550 C with an extrusion ratio of 2.5:1.
The powders produced after milling were investigated by using SEM Model Quanta 250 FEG (Field Emission Gun) attached with EDX unit (Energy Dispersive X-ray Analyses), with accelerating voltage 30 kV. The nanocrystalline nature of the high-energy ball-milled powders was confirmed using a JEOL 3010 highresolution transmission electron microscope (HR-TEM).

sections.heading: 2.2. Uniaxial tensile test
sections.text: To investigate the mechanical behavior of the composites the tensile test was conducted on MTS universal testing machine with a maximum load capacity of 100 KN according to ASTM E8/E8M-11 [23]. The crosshead speed was set at 2 mm/min on the round specimens. Three specimen were tested for each category to check the repeatability of the test.

sections.heading: 2.3. Nano-indentation experiment
sections.text: The nano-indentation test was conducted using a Triboscope system and a Berkovich indenter. A cubic specimen of 3 mm thick with the section area of 10 10 mm2 was prepared from pure aluminum and Al-5 wt.% Al2O3 composite. The surface of specimens was ground with 80–2200 grit sandpapers and then polished by diamond past. After polishing, to ensure the clean of the surface, it is mandatory to use enchant to clean the surface from oxides. Several indentations on the randomly selected sites of the sample were performed in order to obtain five nearly repeatable load–displacement curves from the experiment. Then the average of these curves was used for analysis of experimental results.

sections.heading: 3. Finite element simulation
sections.text:
A 2D axisymmetric model was employed for finite element simulation of the elastic–plastic behavior of material in the nanoindentation process. The finite element model is generated using ANSYS commercial software. A conical rigid indenter with halfangle of 70:3 was used in the axisymmetric model which has the same projected area to depth function as the standard Berkovich indenter. Based on the literature, Lichinchi [19] has reported that the sharpness of the indenter has great effect on the response in nano-indentation experiment. Moreover, the ISO-14577 standard [24] has shown that the Berkovich indenter has an average radius of curvature about 150–200 nm. So, the indenter was simulated as conical indenter with cone tip has a rounding of R = 150 nm. The indenter and specimen were meshed by 2D structural PLANE 182 (Fig. 2). Axisymmetry conditions were applied along the center line. A reasonable fine mesh is required to ensure convergence, a graded mesh is created, where the region in the contact with the indentor is more finely meshed to study the stress distribution under the indenter (see Fig. 2). The interaction of the indenter and the specimen is modeled as a contact pair with no friction. Contact element TARGET169 is applied to the indenter and
tion and FE simulation of nano-indentation on Al–Al2O3 nanocomposites, 21
CONTACT175 to the specimen. Non linear analysis was conducted in this model. Displacement control technique is used to apply the displacement to the indenter in y-direction. Convergence study of FE results is conducted to ensure that the mesh refinement in the composite laminate is sufficiently fine enough to capture the stresses and deformations with reasonably accuracy. The boundary condition was modeled as a fixed support at the lower surface of the specimen to prevent the movements of the lower nodes of the modeled sample, and fixing the horizontal movements along X-axis to meet the Axisymmetry condition.
The mechanical properties obtained from the uniaxial test were used in finite element simulation of the nano-indentation test. Both loading and unloading steps of nano-indentation process were simulated in the finite element model. The indenter was driven into the specimen surface in the axial direction for 250 nm in 5 s and with a constant speed. When the indenter tip reached 250 nm, the test specimen was unloaded and the indenter tip returned to its initial position with the same speed as that of the loading stage. In this way, the un-loading part of the load–displacement curve is obtained from the finite element simulation.
All calculations were carried out using the axisymmetric cylindrical domain characterized by a radius L = 100 lm and height of 50 lm and representing the specimen. The material model used in the present work is elastoplastic model with kinematic hardening and von Mises yield surface. The material response is assumed to be isotropic elastoplastic with exponential hardening following a law, known as Hollomon’s power hardening law obeying von Mises plastic criterion.

sections.heading: 4.1. Morphology and particle distribution
sections.text:
Fig. 3 shows the SEMmicrograph taken to the as received Al and Al2O3 powders and Al-5 wt.% Al2O3 powder samples after 20 h milling. The presence of alumina particles causes more work hardening during ball milling. As a result, more refinement of aluminum and alumina particles were occurred during ball milling. Fig. 3d shows a high magnification for specific part from Fig. 3c, the small particles of alumina seem to be distributed in uniform manner. Also, the particle size of the alumina particles reaches to the nano-sized.
5 wt.% Al2O3 after 20 h milling, and (d) high magnification of Al–5 wt.% Al2O3.
Fig. 4. TEM micrograph of Al–5 wt.% Al2O3 after 20 h milling (a) bright field image (BFI) and (b) dark field image (DFI).
The microstructural characteristic of the Al-5 wt.% Al2O3 powder for a milling time of 20 h was examined by TEM observation. The bright and dark field images are shown in Fig. 4(a) and (b), respectively. The TEM image clearly shows that nano-sized Al2O3 (the white phases in Fig. 4(b)) were homogeneously distributed in Al powders. These results indicate that composite powders with
Please cite this article in press as: A. Wagih, A. Fathy, Experimental investiga Advanced Powder Technology (2016), http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.apt.2016.01.0
a homogenous distribution of nano-sized Al2O3 particles can be obtained by controlled ball milling.
As it was well known, the distribution of reinforcement in the oblique matrix is a critical parameter in the properties of the MMCs. X-ray mapping was carried out on the powders milled to the steady-state condition for 20 h. Fig. 5 shows the mapping
g (a) Al, (b) O, and (c) amount of each component.
tion and FE simulation of nano-indentation on Al–Al2O3 nanocomposites, 21
spectra for the elements aluminum and oxygen in the Al-5 wt.% Al2O3. It may be noted that both aluminum and oxygen are uniformly distributed in the powder. The level of aluminum was much higher than that of oxygen. Aluminum and oxygen spectrums represent the presence of alumina.

sections.heading: 4.2. Young’s modulus and yield strength
sections.text: Table 1 shows the values of young’s modulus and yield strength of Al and Al-5 wt.% Al2O3 nanocomposite after 20 h milling. As it was expected, the elastic modulus is increased by adding the reinforcement particles. Young’s modulus can be calculated from the slope of the elastic part of the curve, and the yield strength is the stress at the end of the elastic part. The proposed values were used as input in the FE model.

sections.heading: 4.3. FE results
sections.text:
The most reliable way to judge the potential of the presented model is by comparing its predictions to experimental results obtained on the same material. Fig. 6 shows the load–indentation curve ðF aÞ obtained from the FE simulation and nanoindentation experimental test for both materials (Pure Al, and Al-5 wt.% Al2O3). The displacement was regarded as the displacement of point (H) which represent the displacement of the indenter tip.
Fig. 6(a) shows a comparison between the curves resulting from FE simulation and from the nano-indentation experimental of pure aluminum metal. The Figure shows good agreement between the FE simulations with a rounded tip indenter and the experiment. However, the agreement between the FE simulations with the sharp indenter tip and the experimental results was so bad. So, a slight curvature of 150 nm was considered for all simulations. As a possible reason for this fact that the indenter used for experiment not perfectly sharp it has small curvature based on the ISO 14577 standard.
Fig. 6(b) shows a comparison between the FE simulation and experimental results for Al-5 wt.% Al2O3 nano composite. The FE simulation achieves a good agreement with the experimental results. The agreement between the FE simulations for pure Al with its experiment is much better than that obtained in the FE simulation for Al-5 wt.% Al2O3 nano composite. That’s due to, the experimental load indentation curve is the average of 20 indentations; some indentations are larger and others are smaller in its response. So, the average of the 20 indentations is plotted in Fig. 6.
One can conclude that, the finite element simulation with a round-tip indenter is appropriate for simulating the nanoindentation process and for investigating the stress and deformation fields around the indenter.
The Von Misses stress contour and deformations around the indenter tip of pure Al, and Al-5 wt.% Al2O3 nano composite obtained from the FE simulations is shown in Figs. 7 and 8. The Von Misses yield criteria assumes that the plastic deformation occurs when the equivalent stress reaches to the yield strength of the material. The equivalent stress can be calculated from: reqv ¼ ffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffi ðr1 r2Þ2 þ ðr2 r3Þ2 þ ðr1 r3Þ2
2
s ð1Þ
Please cite this article in press as: A. Wagih, A. Fathy, Experimental investiga Advanced Powder Technology (2016), http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.apt.2016.01.0
where r1; r2, and r3 are the three principle stresses generating at each node in the sample during the FE simulation of the nanoindentation test.
Figs. 7 and 8 show the Von Misses equivalent stresses during loading and unloading for nano-indentation experiment for Al and Al–Al2O3 nano composite, respectively. Figs. 7(a) and 8(a) show the Von Misses equivalent stresses at the beginning of the indentation test simulation. The maximum stress under the indenter tip is 82.5, and 98.5 MPa for Al, and Al–Al2O3 nanocomposite, respectively, which in fact greater than the yield strength of the composite as observed from the tensile test (see Table 1). Therefore, the plastic deformations occur around the indenter tip at the moment of contact between the indenter and the sample. As the indentation depth increases, the plastic deformation zone increased in both directions (longitudinal and through the thickness) until reach the maximum indentation depth (Figs. 7(b) and 8(b)). During the unloading stage (7(c) and (d), and Fig. 8(c) and (d)) the elastic deformations is decreased gradually to zero and the residual plastic deformations cause the indentation footprint.

sections.heading: 4.4. Hardness evaluation
sections.text:
Before measuring any phenomena (expressing it in numbers), it is very important to know the physical meaning of it. The physical meaning of hardness can be defined as the resistance of material to
experiment.
tion and FE simulation of nano-indentation on Al–Al2O3 nanocomposites, 21
Fig. 7. Von Misses stress contours and deformation of pure Al obtained from the FE simulations.
deformation, indentation, or penetration by means such as abrasion, drilling, impact, scratching, and wear. All previous tests make a footprint into the surface of the specimen (it varies depend on the test and the applied load). The applied force and the size of the footprint are always used to calculate the hardness value. One of the most important method for calculating the hardness is presented by Fischer [25].
In Fischer approach, he used a quite general formula for calculating the hardness:

sections.heading: H ¼ Fmax
sections.text:

ð2Þ
where Fmax is the maximum load and A is the projected area of the contact surface between the sample and the indenter. Fischer introduce an approximate value for the projected area in the nanoindentation test with Berkovich indenter depending on the contact depth:
A 24:5h2c ð3Þ where hc is the contact depth as shown in Fig. 9 and can be calculated as:
hc ¼ hmax ha ð4Þ where hmax is the maximum indentation depth and ha can be defined as:
ha ¼ p 2p he ð5Þ
Please cite this article in press as: A. Wagih, A. Fathy, Experimental investiga Advanced Powder Technology (2016), http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.apt.2016.01.0
where he is the elastic displacement during unloading stage which can be obtained from:
he ¼ hmax hr ð6Þ
where hr is the residual footprint of the indenter in the sample. Substituting with Eq. (6), and (5) in (4) the final formula of hc can be computed as:
hc ¼ 2hmax þ ðp 2Þhrp ð7Þ
After introducing the equations used to calculate the hardness, the most important step is determining the parameters used in this equation from the FE simulation. hmax was obtained from the FE simulation as the displacement of point A in Fig. 9 at the end of loading stage. and hr also was obtained from the FE simulation as the displacement at point A after the unloading stage (shown in Fig. 9 as point B). The computed parameters and the calculated hardness is shown in Table 2.
Table 2 introduce the different parameters obtained from the FE simulations which used to calculate the hardness by Eq. (2) [25]. By comparing the hardness values obtained by experiment and the results from the FE model, we can conclude that there are only small differences between the experimental result and the FE results for both materials. Therefore, FE simulation could be a successful method to determine the hardness not only for bulk materials but also, for metal matrix nano composites (MMCs).
tion and FE simulation of nano-indentation on Al–Al2O3 nanocomposites, 21
Fig. 8. Von Misses stress contours and deformation of Al–5 wt.% Al2O3 nano composite obtained from the FE simulations.

sections.heading: 5. Conclusions
sections.text:
In the present study, a 2-D axisymmetry model was implemented in ANSYS software to simulate the nano-indentation experiment of Al–5 wt.% Al2O3 nanocomposite. The results obtained lead to the following conclusions;
1. The Al–5 wt.% Al2O3 nanocomposites powders can be successfully synthesized using the high energy ball milling technique followed by powder metallurgy method. 2. The Al–5 wt.% Al2O3 composites prepared by the powder metallurgy method show a uniform microstructure in which Al2O3 nanoparticles are distributed evenly in the aluminum matrix. 3. The load–displacement curve obtained from the finite element simulation of round-tip indenter was consistent very well with that determined from the nano-indentation experiment. 4. The difference between the hardness values obtained from the finite element simulation and from the nano-indentation experiment was negligible.
d experiments.
5. Finite element simulation is a powerful device to simulate the indentation process at the Al–5 wt.% Al2O3 nanocomosite.

metadata.abstractText: The main purpose of this paper is to investigate the nano-indentation test method and validation of its finite element simulation (FE). In the first stage, a series of nano-indentation tests were performed on the Al–Al2O3 nanocomposites by using Triboscope system and Berkovich indenter to obtain its hardness. To prepare the Al–Al2O3 nanocomposites, a pre-alloyed powder was milled in a planetary ball mill followed by cold compaction and sintering. Then in the second stage, the nano-indentation process on Al–Al2O3 nanocomposites was simulated by a 2D axisymmetric finite element (FE) model. Using the same projected area to depth function as the standard Berkovich indenter, a conical indenter with half angle 70.3 was considered in simulations. The results showed that, a homogenous distribution of the nanosized Al2O3 particles in the Al matrix was achieved after 20 h milling. The young’s modulus, yield strength, and hardness of the produced nanocomposite were increased than the pure aluminum. The results of load–displacement curve obtained from the finite element simulation of non-sharp indenter showed a good agreement with that obtained from the nano-indentation experiment. The scatter of the FE results than the experimental results in the pure aluminum is smaller than that observed for the nanocomposite. 2016 The Society of Powder Technology Japan.
